BALTIMORE,MD., NOV. 26, 1917.

The Business Board of THE
NEWS-LETTER begs to announce
the election of George W.Wagner,
'20, to the office of assistant business manager.
Hopkins Must Beat State.

There is only one answer to that
St. John's game Saturday: Hopkins must beat State. Our football
team has just one victory to its
credit this season, and there is just
the
one more game to be played.
great majority of the early season
games the team was pitted against
heavy, experienced men and not
even the most optimistic could
have hoped for a string of Hopkins
victories against such teams as
Brown, Carlisle and Swarthmore.
But last Saturday's defeat carried
with it a sting that hurt it was
a bitter dose for any Hopkins man
to ,rwallow. St. John's boasted a
string of defeats, a lot of nerve
and an undownable determination
to lick Hopkins—nothing more—
up to Saturday noon. Meantime,
Hopkins had climbed one-third of
the way to the State championship, tied two strong teams and
made a creditable showing against
three very strong teams, and—
what is much more—Hopkins had

a memorable defeat from last year
to avenge, and she knew it. After
the mass-meeting, bonfire and
demonstration of Friday, Hopkins
was ready to stake its all on Saturday's game.
The story of the game is familiar enough to every one of us.
That much is settled, and we offer
110 excuses, no alibis. Nevertheless, every Hopkins man ought to
be so keenly sore and so fighting
mad and so savagely restless for
revenge that he would give his
right arm for some substantial victim for his seething temper. The
gods have saved us our right arms
—they have already delivered into
our hands the very choicest kind
of a victim: Maryland State College is coming to Hopkins with a
victory over St. John's, confidently
expecting to beat us as she did last
year on Thanksgiving Day of this •
week. To those who were not here
or who have tried to forget it, let
us remind you that State ran
roughshod over us last year, whitewashed us, overwhelmed us 54 to
0. If there is anywhere a Hopkins
man who isn't thirsty for State's
blood, who won't yell and fight
until State is beaten and beaten
badly, he isn't fit to be called a
Hopkins man. Hopkins is fighting mad ; Hopkins wastes about as
much love now on State as she
does on Kaiser Bill. Hopkins must
beat State! Get State! Get State!

The following is a letter from
Louis Young, '18, who is now in
Europe, serving in the United
States Aviation Corps. We take
this opportunity of thanking
"Freshman" for his contributing
and of suggesting that others follow his example. Any news from
any Hopkins man .at the front is
of interest to us all.
October 2nd, 1917,
9.00 P. M.
"Dear Mother,
"I surely have enjoyed the trip
across the Atlantic, the weather
has been great and the sea extremely calm; possibly it was for
these reasons that I did not get
sea-sick. We have had the best on
the ship in all things, which perhaps, have helped us to forget the
conditions under which we lived
at our temporary location on
Long Island.
"Since Thursday evening we
have been in the submarine zone
and have worn life belts at all
times. At the same time a submarine watch was started. We
were honored with this duty it
fell to my lot to be on duty today,
the most dangerous day of our
trip. My post was on the starboard side of the forward navigating bridge, both as to comfort
and as to position a most excellent
post. I was on two and off four
hours for the twenty-four hours
from 5 p. in. yesterday, and now
after eight hours of constant
watching with the glasses I am a

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 26, 1917.

THE NEWS-LETTER'S MAIL BAG

HOPKINS LOSES BITTER STRUGGLE

A Column in Which the Correspondents
Are Allowed Latitude, but Shoulder the Responsibility.

(Continuedfrom page 1)

All letters intended for publication must
be concise.
No attention will be paid to anonymous
letters, but names signed as an evidence of
good faith will not be printed if request is
made that they be omitted.
The publication of a letter is not to be
taken as an indorsement of its views by THE
NEWS-LETTER, which invites the freest discussion of matters of general interest.

Restrictions Upon Freshmen.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—The value of a college life
can never be questioned. These
words have often been heard, but
on nearly every occasion were they
uttered with a different basic
meaning, with reference to different values which may be placed
on college life.
The foundation of all 'culture at
college is the college itself. If it
be a bad one the culture will likewise be bad; if it be a good one
the culture will likewise be good.
Culture at college begins in the
freshman class. If the proper restrictions are put upon the freshman Ile will be benefited by them
and the college spirit will be built
up.
With particular reference to
the restrictions placed upon freshmen at Johns Hopkins much may
be said. Everyone is human, and
any rule that singles out a person
or group of persons to the extent
of embarrassment is sure to meet
with very strong opposition. And
rightly so, for even in gatherings
that may not be of people educated
as we are it is considered very impolite to embarrass anyone, while
in society circles such a thing
would be most rude. Therefore,
such regulations as the wearing of
a freshman cap, the wearing of a
freshman button large enough to
be used for a target and the wearing of black socks, all of which are
too much like advertising features,
are sure to meet with opposition
from the freshmen. If the upperclassmen of Johns Hopkins would
be more free to associate with the
freshmen, treating them like
brothers of one large family, instead of holding their heads above
the freshmen as the Kaiser holds
his head above his people, they
would find that the school spirit of
the University would be increased
three-fold. Such spirit as would
then be exhibited would be freely,
proudly and joyously shown,
whereas the spirit which is now
being exhibited is a spirit which
has fear for one of its causes.
Here; as in many other colleges, a
gross mistake is made and it is a
sad thing that the faculty supports such unjust regulations.
Here it is that so often an honest
school spirit is kept in check; and
because it is kept in check the
freshman very often fails to obtain his first, proper, cultural
training.
J. C. S.
November 20, 1917.

COTILLION DATES DECIDED ON;
THREE TO BE HELD THIS YEAR

The Cotillion Board, composed
of Richard H. Woodward, Jr.
(president), C. Herbert Baxley,
William Gardner, Russel K. Burner, James Lewin, Harold Dail
and Vernon Stuart, held a meeting last Wednesday and formed
plans for the coming year. It was
decided that three big dances
would be held this year, the date
of the first one being set for Friday, December 21.
The cotillions this year will not
cost near as much as they have in
former years, and consequently a
much larger attendance is expected. Even though the cost of the
dances has been lowered, their
usual high standard will be maintained. The exact price of the
dances will be announced in a few
days and the Board hopes that at
least eighty couples will be ready
to start dancing when the orchestra strikes its first chord on December 21.

Lafayette College celebrated her
annual Founder's Day and had
for its guest of honor distinguished men from the nation of
Lafayette,in whose memory the college bears its name. The guest of
honor was General Edmond Vignal, military attache of the French
embassy, who spoke on the topic,
"Science and Engineering in Modern Warfare." On him was conferred the honorary degree of doctor of engineering. The exercises

Hopkins Must Beat State.

There is only one answer to that
St. John's game Saturday: Hopkins must beat State. Our football
team has just one victory to its
credit this season, and there is just
the
one more game to be played.
great majority of the early season
games the team was pitted against
heavy, experienced men and not
even the most optimistic could
have hoped for a string of Hopkins
victories against such teams as
Brown, Carlisle and Swarthmore.
But last Saturday's defeat carried
with it a sting that hurt it was
a bitter dose for any Hopkins man
to ,rwallow. St. John's boasted a
string of defeats, a lot of nerve
and an undownable determination
to lick Hopkins—nothing more—
up to Saturday noon. Meantime,
Hopkins had climbed one-third of
the way to the State championship, tied two strong teams and
made a creditable showing against
three very strong teams, and—
what is much more—Hopkins had

a memorable defeat from last year
to avenge, and she knew it. After
the mass-meeting, bonfire and
demonstration of Friday, Hopkins
was ready to stake its all on Saturday's game.
The story of the game is familiar enough to every one of us.
That much is settled, and we offer
110 excuses, no alibis. Nevertheless, every Hopkins man ought to
be so keenly sore and so fighting
mad and so savagely restless for
revenge that he would give his
right arm for some substantial victim for his seething temper. The
gods have saved us our right arms
—they have already delivered into
our hands the very choicest kind
of a victim: Maryland State College is coming to Hopkins with a
victory over St. John's, confidently
expecting to beat us as she did last
year on Thanksgiving Day of this •
week. To those who were not here
or who have tried to forget it, let
us remind you that State ran
roughshod over us last year, whitewashed us, overwhelmed us 54 to
0. If there is anywhere a Hopkins
man who isn't thirsty for State's
blood, who won't yell and fight
until State is beaten and beaten
badly, he isn't fit to be called a
Hopkins man. Hopkins is fighting mad ; Hopkins wastes about as
much love now on State as she
does on Kaiser Bill. Hopkins must
beat State! Get State! Get State!
Get State!

Letters From Men in Service.

The following is a letter from
Louis Young, '18, who is now in
Europe, serving in the United
States Aviation Corps. We take
this opportunity of thanking
"Freshman" for his contributing
and of suggesting that others follow his example. Any news from
any Hopkins man .at the front is
of interest to us all.
October 2nd, 1917,
9.00 P. M.
"Dear Mother,
"I surely have enjoyed the trip
across the Atlantic, the weather
has been great and the sea extremely calm; possibly it was for
these reasons that I did not get
sea-sick. We have had the best on
the ship in all things, which perhaps, have helped us to forget the
conditions under which we lived
at our temporary location on
Long Island.
"Since Thursday evening we
have been in the submarine zone
and have worn life belts at all
times. At the same time a submarine watch was started. We
were honored with this duty it
fell to my lot to be on duty today,
the most dangerous day of our
trip. My post was on the starboard side of the forward navigating bridge, both as to comfort
and as to position a most excellent
post. I was on two and off four
hours for the twenty-four hours
from 5 p. in. yesterday, and now
after eight hours of constant
watching with the glasses I am a

Restrictions Upon Freshmen.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—The value of a college life
can never be questioned. These
words have often been heard, but
on nearly every occasion were they
uttered with a different basic
meaning, with reference to different values which may be placed
on college life.
The foundation of all 'culture at
college is the college itself. If it
be a bad one the culture will likewise be bad; if it be a good one
the culture will likewise be good.
Culture at college begins in the
freshman class. If the proper restrictions are put upon the freshman Ile will be benefited by them
and the college spirit will be built
up.
With particular reference to
the restrictions placed upon freshmen at Johns Hopkins much may
be said. Everyone is human, and
any rule that singles out a person
or group of persons to the extent
of embarrassment is sure to meet
with very strong opposition. And
rightly so, for even in gatherings
that may not be of people educated
as we are it is considered very impolite to embarrass anyone, while
in society circles such a thing
would be most rude. Therefore,
such regulations as the wearing of
a freshman cap, the wearing of a
freshman button large enough to
be used for a target and the wearing of black socks, all of which are
too much like advertising features,
are sure to meet with opposition
from the freshmen. If the upperclassmen of Johns Hopkins would
be more free to associate with the
freshmen, treating them like
brothers of one large family, instead of holding their heads above
the freshmen as the Kaiser holds
his head above his people, they
would find that the school spirit of
the University would be increased
three-fold. Such spirit as would
then be exhibited would be freely,
proudly and joyously shown,
whereas the spirit which is now
being exhibited is a spirit which
has fear for one of its causes.
Here; as in many other colleges, a
gross mistake is made and it is a
sad thing that the faculty supports such unjust regulations.
Here it is that so often an honest
school spirit is kept in check; and
because it is kept in check the
freshman very often fails to obtain his first, proper, cultural
training.
J. C. S.
November 20, 1917.

COTILLION DATES DECIDED ON;
THREE TO BE HELD THIS YEAR

The Cotillion Board, composed
of Richard H. Woodward, Jr.
(president), C. Herbert Baxley,
William Gardner, Russel K. Burner, James Lewin, Harold Dail
and Vernon Stuart, held a meeting last Wednesday and formed
plans for the coming year. It was
decided that three big dances
would be held this year, the date
of the first one being set for Friday, December 21.
The cotillions this year will not
cost near as much as they have in
former years, and consequently a
much larger attendance is expected. Even though the cost of the
dances has been lowered, their
usual high standard will be maintained. The exact price of the
dances will be announced in a few
days and the Board hopes that at
least eighty couples will be ready
to start dancing when the orchestra strikes its first chord on December 21.
